raw_text:
Ireland surge past Scots
 
 Ireland maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield.
 
 Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points. The home side started with tremendous intensity and dominated territory and possession in the opening 10 minutes. A powerful charge from flanker Jason White was carried on by Ali Hogg and when Ireland conceded a penalty close to their own line, Scotland kicked it to touch. The Irish defence foiled the home side on that occasion, but a stray hand in a ruck allowed Paterson to stroke over a penalty in the eighth minute.
 
 If that was a paltry reward for their early pressure, Scotland got the try they deserved when Paterson's searing break and Andy Craig's pass sent Southwell streaking to the right corner. Paterson was off target with the conversion and fly-half Dan Parks then missed a presentable drop-goal attempt. Ireland got themselves on the scoreboard with an O'Gara penalty and by the 24th minute the visitors were ahead. Stuart Grimes pulled down O'Kelly at a line-out, Ireland kicked the penalty to touch and from the set-piece, the big lock was driven over by the rest of his pack.
 
 O'Gara added the conversion and a further penalty, after Shane Horgan almost grabbed a second try from O'Gara's chip to the corner, only for the ball to spill from his hand. But Ireland still delivered a hammer blow to Scotland's hopes just before the interval. O'Connell - skipper in the absence of Brian O'Driscoll - powered through Parks' weak tackle after a free-kick from a scrummage to burrow over.
 
 Scotland suffered a further blow on the resumption when Ireland flanker Johnny O'Connor won another vital turnover, and O'Gara's basketball pass sent Hickie over in the left corner. O'Gara converted and then thumped over a 40m penalty to give the visitors a commanding 28-8 advantage. Scotland looked bereft of ideas but a half-break from Paterson sparked them back to life just before the hour. Stuart Grimes won a line-out and a well-worked move saw Petrie scuttle round the side of the ruck to dive over in the left corner. But it proved a false dawn, and Ireland reasserted their authority in the final 10 minutes. Peter Stringer and O'Kelly combined to put giant prop Hayes over in the right corner before replacement Gavin Duffy scorched away on the left, David Humphreys adding the final flourish with a touchline conversion.
 
 : C Paterson; S Danielli, A Craig, H Southwell, S Lamont; D Parks, C Cusiter; T Smith, G Bulloch (capt), G Kerr; S Grimes, S Murray; J White, A Hogg, J Petrie.
 
 R Russell, B Douglas, N Hines, J Dunbar, M Blair, G Ross, B Hinshelwood.
 
 G Murphy; G Dempsey, S Horgan, K Maggs, D Hickie, R O'Gara, P Stringer; R Corrigan, S Byrne, J Hayes, M O'Kelly, P O'Connell, S Easterby, J O'Connor, A Foley.
 
 F Sheahan, M Horan, D O'Callaghan, E Miller, G Easterby, D Humphreys, G Duffy.
 
 Joel Jutge (France)
llama3.2:1b:
Ireland surge past Scotland
Ireland won 28-8 against Scotland at Murrayfield
Scotland led 8-0 in the first half
Ireland dominated territory and possession in the opening 10 minutes
Jason White carried a powerful charge that Ireland conceded to touch on the home side's line
Ireland scored an O'Gara penalty to take the lead after 24 minutes
The Irish continued to dominate in the second half, scoring tries from Southwell and Hickie and adding conversions and penalties

Scotland struggled to score points in the final 10 minutes of the match
llama3.2:3b: Ireland defeated Scotland 28-8 at Murrayfield to maintain their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions.
Hugo Southwell's early try gave Scotland an 8-0 lead but Ireland responded with three tries from Malcolm O'Kelly and Denis Hickie, along with 13 points from Ronan O'Gara.
Scotland scored two more tries through Jon Petrie, but Ireland sealed the win with late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy.
gemma2:2b: Ireland won against Scotland in the Six Nations with a strong performance.
Ireland scored three tries and a penalty while outscoring Scotland by a significant margin.
John Hayes and Gavin Duffy were key for Ireland.
Scotland had an early lead, but was ultimately unable to capitalize on their opportunities.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ireland won the Six Nations Grand Slam by defeating Scotland at Murrayfield, scoring six tries for Ireland and none for Scotland.
The winning team will face England in Lansdowne Road next week.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland overcame Scotland in the Six Nations Grand Slam match.
qwen2.5:3b: Ireland defeated Scotland 34-8 in the Six Nations, maintaining their Grand Slam ambitions.
The Irish scored two tries and three penalties by Ronan O’Gara to take a commanding lead before half-time.
Despite early pressure, Scotland failed to capitalize on opportunities.
Ireland extended their lead with another try from Denis Hickie and a further penalty, putting the game beyond doubt.
In the second half, Johnny O'Connor won a turnover, leading to Paul O'Connell’s touchdown, followed by tries for Jon Petrie and Gavin Duffy.
Scotland could only manage one more score in reply through Stuart Grimes’ try.
Ireland won their second consecutive away match and await England next fortnight, while Scotland aim to win their first Six Nations game against Italy.
opencoder:1.5b: Ireland's defeat over Scotland in Murrayfield, the opening match, was a tumultuous one.
The Scots triumphed with a 8-0 lead, but Ireland scored from locks and had three penalties.
Their six-year Grand Slam ambitions were met with intense resistance, but when they finally turned their nose to play again, England won the match.
England struggled but managed to turn pressure into points, while Ireland secured themselves on the scoreboard with a penalty for a conversion by O'Gara in the 20th minute.
Stammers grappled with England's attempt at two unsuccessful away victories before they came to an impasse when they found out they had missed their first six-match victory.
The home side continued with phenomenal intensity and dominance, while England saw territory but couldn't win a point.
It was only later that Scotland tackled the Irish match, which gave them a chance to give their coach Matt Williams a first place finish when Italy came to Edinburgh.
smollm:1.7b: The Irish maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ireland won a thrilling 28-8 match against the Scottish rugby team at Murrayfield, showcasing their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions.
Hugo Southwell led with a try, but the Scots started strong, extending their lead to 8-0 early on.
The visitors, Irregulars (Irregulars), quickly built an advantage scoring from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell.
A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a penalty from Ronan O'Gara gave the Irish team significant momentum by half-time.
With Eddie O'Sullivan leading their side, they managed to secure two hard-earned away victories against stronger opponents.
On Saturday, at Lansdowne Road, Eddie O'Sullivan's team faces England for their second chance of a Six Nations title.
The game is expected to be intense with some high-profile substitutions and notable performances from players like Jason White and Stuart Grimes.
tinyllama:1.1b: After a tough start to the Six Nations Grand Slam race, Ireland managed to hold off Scotland in a high-intensity match at Murrayfield.
The visitors had a lead after the first half, but some impressive individual performances by players like Paterson and Southwell helped Ireland seal their second victory of the tournament.
This victory also marks Eddie O'Suilleabhain's first Grand Slam triumph as coach, following the departure of his predecessor Matt Williams in 2019.
The match was marred by injuries to key players like Humphries and Murray, but Ireland managed to withstand Scotland's pressure and secure a deserved victory.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Six Nations Grand Slam was secured for Ireland with a resilient victory against Scotland at Murrayfield.
In an exhilarating display of skill and determination, the Irish side overwhelmed their hosts and emerged victorious despite facing significant pressure early on.
They were particularly impressive in the first half, dominating territory and possession, and proving too much for Scotland's forwards in the opening ten minutes.
The second half saw a much-needed push from Scotland to mount a comeback but it was not enough to break Ireland's stranglehold on the game.
A powerful charge from flanker Jason White and an impressive display of skill by Ali Hogg put Ireland in control early on, with the Irish team dominating territory and possession.
If that was a palatable reward for their efforts, Scotland got the try they deserved when Paterson's searing break and Andy Craig's pass found Southwell streaking to the right corner.
The Irish defence, foiled initially, but a stray hand in a ruck allowed Paterson to stroke over a penalty in the eighth minute.
If that was a palatable reward for their early pressure, Scotland got the try they deserved when Paterson's searing break and Andy Craig's pass sent Southwell across the whitewash.
The Irish team got themselves on the scoreboard with an O'Gara penalty and by the 24th minute, the visitors were ahead.
Stuart Grimes buried a winning penalty to send Scotland into halftime with a 5-point lead.
The second half began with both teams looking for a way back into the game.
Ireland came close with a penalty taken by O'Gara but the visitors struggled to find their rhythm and errors allowed Scotland to take the lead early in the second half.
Malcolm O'Kelly's try added insult to injury as Scotland secured a narrow victory against Ireland.
The win sends Ireland into the quarter-finals where they will face France next month.

The home team started strong but Scotland took the lead with two tries from Hugo Southwell's try-line clearance.
However, Ireland scored three tries and two penalties in the second half to take the victory by 14 points.
The Irish coach, Matt Williams, was hopeful of a first Six Nations win against Italy later in the week, but Scotland struggled to convert pressure into points on this occasion.

After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight.
Scotland will try to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

hermes3:3b: Ireland Beats Scotland in Six Nations Game
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ireland secured a crucial Six Nations Grand Slam victory against Scotland at Murrayfield, maintaining their strong performance throughout the match.
Ireland took an early lead with a penalty and went on to score two tries through Hugo Southwell and Paul O'Connell, as well as three penalties from Ronan O'Gara.
Despite a late try by Jon Petrie for Scotland, Ireland sealed the victory with additional tries from Peter Stringer and Gavin Duffy, eventually winning 27-17.
This hard-earned win puts Ireland on track for a potential Grand Slam, looking forward to facing England in two weeks.
In contrast, Scotland struggled to turn pressure into points and will look to improve under their new coach Matt Williams when they host Italy in Edinburgh.

Despite an early 8-0 lead for Scotland through Hugo Southwell’s try and Chris Paterson’s penalty, Ireland took control with tries from Malcolm O’Kelly and Paul O’Connell, leading 18-8 at halftime.
Denis Hickie’s try and Ronan O’Gara’s accurate kicking extended Ireland’s advantage.
Scotland responded with a Jon Petrie try, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed a convincing Irish victory.
Eddie O’Sullivan’s team now prepares to face England, while Scotland, struggling to convert pressure into points, will seek their first Six Nations win under Matt Williams against Italy.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Ireland secured a 28-15 victory over Scotland at Murrayfield during the Six Nations, extending their Grand Slam hopes.
Despite early pressure from Scotland, Ireland took the lead through Hugo Southwell's try and scores from Malcolm O'Kelly, Paul O'Connell, Denis Hickie, and Ronan O'Gara.
Ireland dominated territory and possession, with O'Connell scoring a crucial try and O'Gara adding multiple conversions and penalties.
Scotland managed late tries from Jason Petrie and Jonny Petrie but couldn't overcome the deficit.
Following this win, Ireland will face England at Lansdowne Road next week.
